item.description:
From the publisher's website:

Welcome to the Department of Homeland Security shell game. Hand over your Rights and the DHS will protect you from the bad guys. Although the Department of Homeland Security cannot actually protect you from terrorists and random acts of violence, they sure can make it look like they’re doing something (or, in the face of hurricane Katrina, maybe not). A façade of security so you can feel safe (without actually being safe).

Feel Safe, The Game of Homeland Security is a satirical board game in which players start off with ten Rights (as per the Bill of Rights) and must exchange those Rights for perceived security and safety, the first player to lose or give away all of their Rights (in the name of national security) wins the game.
A Swedish roll & move game having to do with building a house. Nicely illustrated with high-quality box and board.

You win when you make the Hot Tomato jump across the play area and into the scoring tray. Win 8 rounds and you've won the game. Players make the Hot Tomato jump by pressing one of the five keys on their side.

Bumps and Grinds

A hilarious drinking and stripping game.

(Any number can play)

For the first time here is an imaginative game whereby the rules require candle light and your favorite drinks. To create the proper atmosphere the game at first allows for more drinking due to various safety's but as Bumps and Grinds progresses and the first bashful blush is forgotten, more and more clothing is shed.

Hilarious situations are created when a player has to "Go Directly to Bar" or luckily draws a "False Modesty Card" as a temporary safety in lieu of removing one article of clothing.

When any one player is down to his or her last article of clothing and is about to lose that, he or she may blow out the candle and be declared the winner of Bumps and Grinds.

Players receive a green card with the sentence "Have U It?" on it and an equal amount of red counters. Each letter has a corresponding number next to it in red. The first player picks a card from the deck and checks to see if the letter and number coincide with his card. If it does, he places the card face-up in front of him If not, he calls out the combination and all players check their cards. The player who needs it takes the card. When someone fills their card, they yell "I have it". All players pay him in red counters the total value according to the numbers of the letters which they are missing.

Brother Parker, a game company owner, has invited six detectives to a mystery party game. Upon arriving, the detectives find their host dead and must solve his murder.

Provided in the game are instructions for the murder mystery party as well as scripts, clues, and the solution to the mystery.

The object of the game is to pin the guilt on one of the players. To avoid guilt, players strive to obtain certain combinations of cards which prove their innocence by providing an alibi or by proving that they were witnesses.

Khan Tsin is a two-player game. The board is a dragon without a head or tail. Markers representing barons are placed along the dragon. Each turn the active player moves one of the four closest barons onto another baron. A stack of barons may contain at most three of one color the three colors of barons. The player to complete a stack with three barons of each of the three colors wins.

item.description:
Gundam Collection Tactical Combat is a miniature tabletop wargame with collectible components.Players collect teams of Mobile Suits ( Giant Robots) with different powers and abilities from the Anime Gundam , and battle each other on a tabletop using rulers and 1/400 scenery.

Actually , there are two miniatures systems: the first , and older, using the statistics in the base of the miniature , and a new and more advanced system called Tactical Combat with specific and expert rules.

The scale is 1/400 ( 4/5 cm).

Players have been invited to the reading of Ms. Lotta Bux's will. They discover that she has been murdered and must discover who among them is the murderer.

Another murder mystery party game in the series by Penny and Tom Warner. Provided in the game are player scripts, clues, a list of needed props, and the solution to the murder mystery.

Text from the back of the game:
A preferably long word with Y? How about x-y-l-o-p-h-o-n-s-p-i-e-l-e-r (xylophone player)? Of course d-e-s-o-x-y-r-i-b-o-n-u-c-l-e-i-n-s-ä-u-r-e (DNA) is much, much better, because it will give you a lot of points! But will it fit into the crossword grid? And where? Where is the next letter situated? You've got to be fast, because the sand in the hourglass is running. And all the other players have entered their words already...

The fast game of words for all crossword-lovers, who like to juggle with letters.

This variant of Nine Men's Morris adds "blocking" positions to the standard board. Each time a player gets three-in-a-row, he removes a piece of his opponent, but also adds a blocking pin to the line with his three-in-a-row. This block then prevents said player from making another three-in-a-row along the same line. This additional element removes some of the simplest winning patterns from the standard game. The gameboard (from 1923) includes extra spaces for the blocking pins.

Balance Duels is a SPIEL 2005 release by a tiny Dutch publisher. The game is played like backgammon, except that the track is a teeter-totter and players cannot make a move that would put the device out of balance.

item.description:
(From the box) 198 fragments of mainly original hits. Who van recognize the artist, the title or the country of origin and be the first to finish his "Compact Disc"?

Contents: 1 dice, 6 "Compact Discs" (in 8 pieces, SW), 1 rule/answer book, 1 game CD (with 99 tracks, each containing two parts, SW) and 1 CD with 25 Golden hits (not part of the actual game but a bonus, SW).

Mercante in Fiera (=Merchant at the Fair) is a popular game in Italy. Earlier, it was played with 2 decks of 40 cards, nowadays the 2 decks contain 55 cards. A pack shows different illustrations on every card; the second deck is an exact copy of the first one, except the back being different.

The game is played in 2 phases. During phase 1, all the cards of one deck are sold by auctions of 1-4 cards each.

Phase 2 is played with the second deck. Before starting, the winning cards are drawn from deck 2 and the paid jetons from phase 1 are put on these cards.

The remaining cards are revealed card after card and the players having these cards must discard them. The more cards are revealed, the more the chance of having one of the winning cards increases. Players are allowed to trade among each other anytime during phase 2. Such trades are more likely towards the end of the game.

Winner is the player with the most jetons.

Mercante in fiera is a newer version with new graphics, contents and updated game flow.

item.description: Mézclalas is a children's game designed to educate native speakers of Spanish, with sounds and letters. The first to make it all around the board wins!
Three Bear Family Honeycomb Hike is a children's game (suggested for ages 3-6) designed to teach children colors, sizes, and the beginnings of numbers.

Kampen om Linköping is a game about the Swedish city of Linköping. The mechanics is, roughly, a mix of Monopoly and Trivial Pursuit where most of the questions are about the city and its history.

Home Page: http://www.kunskapsspelet.se
Kasserine is a simulation of the dramatic Axis offensive in Tunisia during February of 1943. The target of this carefully timed operation was the U.S. II Corps. Part of the North Africa Quad.

Pai Gow is a traditional Chinese gambling game played with a special set of 32 dominoes (see Chinese Dominoes). Everyone plays against a banker. Each player gets dealt four dominoes and makes two pairs. A player wins (loses) if each matching pair is better (worse) than the dealers. If they split, it's a draw. The only decision made in the game is how to split the original four tiles.

Because of the rules, the game is often a draw. The ranking of hands is traditional and not obvious. For example, the best pair is (4/2)(2/1).

A derivative of Whist with two significant differences: (1) the game is a two-player game and does not involve partnerships and (2) because, unlike Whist, only half the deck is dealt, the game begins with additional series of non-scoring tricks in which each trick determines how the top two cards of the draw deck are dealt to the players, the winner of each trick getting the top card (which is always revealed before the trick is played) and the losing player getting the second (hidden) card.

The game is a quick to learn, easy to arrange, and fast-playing introduction to trick-taking games and serves as a good first step to learning to play Whist or Bridge for players unfamiliar with trick-taking.

From the back of the box:

"Features three exciting games with colorful and detailed dinosaur cards. Younger players will enjoy Go Dino!, based on the traditional game "Go Fish". Use your memory and observation skills to play Dino Search. And real dinosaur fans will want to play Dino Challenge, a game that pits dinosaur against dinosaur. 53 fact-filled cards add to the fun!"

The box also says: Ages 5+.

A set of miniature wargame rules for the Ancient period, encompassing early Greeks through Norman Conquest.

"Battlestandard" was designed as a moderate-complexity treatment of Ancient warfare fitting between some recent, simpler Ancients systems and the highly detailed systems that have been hobby staples for many years.

The basing system is compatible with most existing Ancients rule systems, allowing players to use these rules without changing already-based armies. Army lists are provided for Philippian/Alexandran Macedonian; Late Achaemenid Persian; Roman Marian/Caesarian; Celtic/Gallic Barbarian; Norman Conquest; and Late Saxon armies.

Turn sequence is determined through an initiative system. Armor and Shield protection is key to defining defensive capabilities. Multiple categories of mounted, infantry and missile troops are distinguished. Leadership is represented through several tiers of Leaders.

The system is primarily geared for 25/28mm figures. Conversion instructions are included for 15mm and 40mm armies. Armies usually compose from 100 to 300 figures per side; the standard system figure ratio is 1?40.

Army statistics, including General characteristics, War Machine attributes and Army List Templates are recorded on copies of forms provided with the rules. Referral to these lists suffice for determining combat and morale outcomes in a game. Games featuring armies of this size can be completed in three to four hours once the system is understood.

Publisher website: www.battlestandard.com

Several colorful worms are hiding in the earth (slots in the game box). Only their head is showing, their tail (different length - 6-9 segments) is hidden. Now Flip the bird is trying to pull them out of their hiding place.

Each player rolls a die (that shows the numbers 2-6, and a wild card). He moves Flip that number of spaces along his track. If there is a worm at this spot, he pulls out that many segments. If this pulls out the worm completely, he collects it. Goal is to collect 3 worms.

Ages 4 and up.

New Essen 2006 game from Kosmos and Reiner Knizia which deals with the typically characteristics and relationships of women and men.

item.description:
Witches, ghosts and bats are racing against each other. Those that reach the goal on the game board first will yield the most points for the players. At the same time, however the players must achieve individual goals by cleverly playing their cards. The one that does this best, will get the most points. And that leads to conflict quickly!

The board is placed in the middle of the table with 3 coloured markes placed on it. On their turn, a player lays a card: he can lay it in front of himself to try to improve his chances, or in front of another player to make the completion of their tasks more difficult for them. You may even play cards face down to cover a face up card (your own or an opponent’s). With each card played, the same coloured marker is moved. That means that all markers can be moved by all players. The finishing order of the 3 markers determines the sequence for the 3 tasks. Now the points are calculated for each player, and after 4 rounds the winner is the player with the most points.

A new title of the Kosmos 2 player games. Each player has to collect cards with holiday-themes, so each player creates his own "dream holidays". Released in Essen 2006.

Summertime is part of the Kosmos two-player series.

item.description: Five Field Kono is a traditional Korean game of position and blockade. It is played by two players, using seven pieces each, on a square board of 5x5 points. Each piece can move one square diagonally. There is no capture or jumping. The object of the game is to move all seven pieces to the opposite end of the board, where the opponent's pieces started. The first player to do this wins the game.

item.description: Kids improve their reading and listening comprehension skills without even realizing it! Players read a riddle, then move across game board maze to collect the tile with the riddle's answer. Maze pieces, which can be rearranged, allow for multiple ways to reach the answer tiles. The first player to collect three riddle cards wins. Double-sided tiles provides two levels of play. For 2-4 players. Includes game board, 81 tile cards, 80 riddle cards and instructions.
Subtraction in the Safari is an educational game, one in a series of four, that is designed to help children learn subtraction.
Addition in the Amazon is an educational game, one in a series of four, that is designed to help children learn addition.

From the rules:
"The WHOOPIES are strange creatures from a distant planet called Whoops. Nobody can explain why thousands of them just fell on our planet. They are surprisingly like some animals living on our planet and we would like to adopt them all unfortunately, they cannot be tamed and playing is all they ever think about: they run, jump, throw themselves everywhere, thus damaging many things. We have to prevent them from creating chaos in our homes by catching them."

The game comes with five cuddly toys (Phanteus, Octopus, Torteus, Marsupus and Ursinus), 5 cords with a wooden ball, 20 gems, 1 die and 6 stickers.

The six sides of the die are: Whoopies' color, Whoopies' hair color, Whoopies' name, all Whoopies but one, A Whoopie for everyone, and double points round.

You roll the die and chose a Whoopie based on the catagory. Hold all the Whoopies by the tail above the table and drop them. The person to grab the right Whoopie (by the end of the tail!!) gets a gem and anybody to grab the wrong one (or the right one not by the end) loses some gems.

Warning: "During the action, the cord may get loose from the Whoopie. The game goes on and the players shall catch the right Whoopie by the binding of its tail."

item.description:
Hooker and Lee is a battle-level simulation of the engagement at Chancellorsville on May 2nd and 3rd, 1863. Union General Joe Hooker had just completed a brilliant strategic maneuver, trapping Lee's Army of Northern Virginia. Hooker's failure to follow up this stroke not only enabled Lee to escape the trap, but also allowed Lee to inflict a tactical beating on the Union Army. Unfortunately, Confederate casualties made theirs a Pyhrric victory.

This game is part of the Quadrigame "Blue & Gray II". Can be combined with Fredericksburg to play Grand Chancellorsville.

Fredericksburg is a tactical level simulation of the battle between Ambrose E. Burnside's Army of the Potomac and Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia. During the bloody battle, 114,873 soldiers took the field and were hurled against 74,867 well-fortified Confederates. The result was predictable: an easy victory for the Confederacy.

This game is part of the Quadrigame Blue & Gray II. Can be combined with Hooker and Lee to play Grand Chancellorsville.

Chattanooga is a tactical level simulation of the battle between General Ulysses Grant, commanding the Armies of the Cumberland and of the Tennessee, and General Braxton Bragg, commanding the Army of Tennessee. This game is part of the Quadrigame "Blue & Gray II"

Battle of the Wilderness is a tactical level simulation of the battle between the Union Army of the Potomac and the Confederate Army of the Northern Virginia, which took place during early May, 1864, in the area south of the Rapidan River in Virginia known as "the Wilderness."

This game is part of the Quadrigame "Blue & Gray II"

Dominoes with the numbers replaced by musical notes and/or key signatures. The notes and/or key signatures must match to lay a tile.

An early version of Musical Dominoes was published by Theodore Dresser in 1893. C.W. Grimm was credited as the inventor. This set came with 36 dominoes marked with two equal squares in which note value signs ranging from a whole to a sixteenth were printed. The game came with two instruction booklets: "How to Play Musical Dominoes" and "How to Give Musical Domino Parties." The latter booklet explained six game variations.
Travel Sorry! is the travel version of the old Sorry game. Instead of cards, a spinner is used to determine your movement, and you have two pieces instead of four.

item.description: “Battle” is a deluxe version of the traditional battleship pencil and paper game. There are several significant additions to this new game. The playing grid is a larger 15 by 22 playing area that contains both land and water squares. The forces of both sides contain ships for the water squares, gun batteries for the land squares, and air formations that can occupy either type of square. Players alternate shots by calling out grid locations. The objective is simply to seek and destroy the opposing force before your own force is destroyed.

Players compete in a quest through a challenging maze of thought-provoking and brain-teasing word definitions. Travel around the word quest game board, collecting letters from words to attain your final word quest and win the game.

name.value: Griddly Headz Baseball Game: Deluxe Edition

item.description:
One of seven in the line of Griddly Headz Boardgames, Baseball sees a different cast of “Griddly Headz” (regular Joes) duking it out on the diamond for ultimate supremacy.

Played on a large, two-tiered board, Griddly Headz features the chance to choose both your players and how you match up them up against your opponent’s team.

Gameplay consists of numerous dice challenges that take place when two players meet on the same play square of the board; the loser forfeits a piece of their gear (represented by puzzle pieces). If a player loses all twelve pieces of their gear, or one of their Griddly Headz is ejected from the game, they are immediately eliminated from the game.

To win, you must score 10 runs.

Available in Special, Deluxe, Family, and Mini editions.

item.description:
The Dice Hockey game set features three top quality, 18mm molded dice which look and feel like natural pearl, along with an attractive pocket size container with easy-off cap, detailed guidelines and two copies of brief game rules tabulated for quick reference.

Although usually played One-on-One, DICE HOCKEY may be played by two teams with each player taking turns in rotation.

Players first agree on the number of goals to be scored to win or the number of minutes to be played.

Offense rolls the Red die to show PASS, UP ICE, FOULED, OFFSIDE or SHOOT (2 faces).

Defense waits until Offense rolls SHOOT or FOULED, then retaliates by rolling the Blue die to show BLOCK , TURN-OVER, ICED, GOAL or SAVED (2 faces).

A new Face-Off results when OFFSIDE, ICED or GOAL is rolled and a Power Play results when FOULED shows up.

A game tied at the time limit may be decided by either of two ‘Sudden Death’ options.

When there’s no Ice Hockey...
Play DICE HOCKEY!

All you need is a reasonably flat surface and a thirst for ACTION!!

Multiplication Monsters Of The Deep is an educational game, one in a series of four, that is designed to help children learn multiplication.

from the publisher:

Try this fast-paced card game alternative to flashcards! Players practice multiplication facts for numbers 2 through 9. Colorful illustrations add a self-checking aspect. Great for classroom activity centers or home use. Game includes 128 laminated playing cards, interesting animal facts and multilingual instruction book. For 2–4 players, grades 2–5.

item.description:
This game was published in the German zine "Pöppel-Revue" 6/86. According to the description, the original title of this game from Derek Carver was "Loot".

6 or 8 (!) players start with 2 treasure hunters and 1 guard in the middle the board to search for 16 treasures of different value. The board has 8 rings with an increasing number of spaces on them; the 16 treasures are placed at some of the 28 outer spaces of the board.

The tokens can have 4 different colors and 4 different shapes in a 8-player's game (3 and 3 in a 6-player's game), but each player has 3 equal tokens. That means, one player may have 3 blue round tokens, another 3 red square tokens, a next 3 yellow hex tokens, and so on - each color and shape on a total of 6 tokens.

Unique is the idea, that treasures can only be dug out by more than 1 player! How many and what kind of tokens are needed, is marked on each treasure chest, which covers the treasure (e.g. 3 tokens of different shape, or 4 tokens of 4 different colors).

Once, a treasure is dug out, it belongs to the whole group of tokens, but it must be transported back to the middle of the game board, where only 1 player can claim it. Needless to say, that several alliances, (broken) promises and other bluffs are usual, especially since the guard pieces can attack the hunters to steal the treasures from them.

The game ends, when all treasures are dug out, or when one player has claimed a certain amount of treasures - or when a certain time limit is reached.

The goal of the game is to reach the end of the track first.

How do you play?
The first player spins the top quickly or slowly in the hole in the board. Then they count to 10 and flip over a card depicting a configuration of blocks in a stack. Everyone has their own set of blocks and must complete the construction before the top stops spinning to advance.

Notes: If some one's scoring marker is on top of yours and you advance you will carry their scoring marker along with yours. There's also a couple short cuts on the track that can only be taken if your are carrying someone or if you're carrying no more than one other person. Also, there are a couple spots you can stop and help someone else complete their construction so that they can catch up and you can take the short cut together, etc.

item.description:
Member of the Alhambra, and a stand-alone game with the same box-size as Alhambra.

Each player tries to get the most victory points. The game goes over five rounds giving a scoring after the 1st, 3rd and 5th round. Victory points are awarded for majorities of allocated buildings (very similar to the original game Alhambra). To get the buildings you roll 8 dice each showing the six building-symbols. Each player has 3 rolls on his turn to get as many similar symbols as possible (up to a max of 8). A player can only note his result for one type of building. The results of the dice rolls from every player is marked on the game board. So everybody can compare his dice rolls with those of the other players. After a round is completed the player with the highest dice-roll can choose between 2 buildings of the respective category or 1 building and a special counter giving a certain bonus. (Bonuses can be: additional 1-3 VPs, extra dice-roll, exchange one building, determine Starting player, etc.) The second best player in that category will get the other part. Each round has a certain number of turns depending on how many players are playing (3, 4 or 5 turns). So, because a player can only hit one type of building during his turn, he cannot score all 6 types of buildings in a single round. After round #1, #3 and #5 the majority in each building category is awarded the same way like in Alhambra. The player with the most VP's wins the game.

Special: There is a variant in which you can combine the building counters of the Alhambra game which adds some building strategy.

Integrates with:

 Alhambra

item.description:
Monster in the Cabbages is a dice game for two to five players. Monster in the Cabbages uses about 8 six-sided dice, a cup, and pencil and paper. A four-player game takes about 25 minutes to play. Monster in the Cabbages is appropriate for ages 10 and older.

Your goal is to harvest as many cabbages as you can. However. there’s a Monster in the cabbage field that needs to be fed. If everyone ignores the Monster, it’ll get so hungry that it’ll eat everyone (Everyone loses the game if this happens.). That means that you have to balance your need to harvest cabbages with the threat of letting the Monster in the Cabbages eat everyone.

On your turn you can Harvest Cabbages or Feed the Monster.

If you choose to Harvest Cabbages, roll two dice and add them to your score (under Cabbages).

If you choose to Feed the Monster remove a die from the Monster Cup, mark a Feeding on your paper, then roll the dice in the Monster Cup (see below for the possible ramifications of this).

If the Monster Cup is between you and the next player at the end of your turn, it gets to take a turn. On the Monster Cup’s turn, add a die to it, then roll the dice in the Monster Cup. When the Monster Cup’s turn is over, move it to your right.

When you roll the Monster Dice: If the Monster Dice total 25 or greater, or if the Monster Dice show three or more identical results (triples or better), the game ends.

If the game ended because the Monster Dice roll was 25 or greater, the Monster in the Cabbages got too hungry and ate all of you (the game wins and all of the players lose).

If the game ended because the Monster Dice rolled triples, cross reference the triples rolled with the following table to determine the winner:

1 or 2: The player with the most cabbages wins. Ties go to the player with the least number of feedings removed.
3 or 4: The player who did the most feedings wins. Ties go to the player with the least cabbages.
5 or 6: Multiply your cabbages by your number of feedings. If your result is the biggest, you win. Ties are shared victories.

item.description:
The Universal Soldier Miniature Rules (1977, RAFM) is a stand-alone comprehensive set of rules for wargaming with military miniatures (25mm or 15mm). The emphasis of the rules is to provide a method for fighting battles with both historical and fictional armies. The rules include simple, easy to remember, combat and missile fire systems that use six-sided dice.

Chapters cover how to form units, orders, movement, missile fire, melee combat, morale, control, fatigue, and special weapons and tactics. There is some simultaneous movement allowed, which will sometimes require pro-rating moves to determine where units contact. Units are rated for attack and defense, using a letter system ("A" being the best, "E" being the worst). There are three ranges for missile-armed troops, as well as ammunition rules. About 6-24 six-sided dice are needed, depending on the size of the game. This is a casualty-removal system. There is a point system for designing games with balanced sides.

Most of the examples and scenarios are from the late medieval / early renaissance period, but the rules can be applied to earlier periods.

Although an old set of rules, it was a good miniatures rules set for new players that wanted to try tabletop miniatures wargaming, and less complex than other contemporary miniatures rules of the time that covered the ancient through medieval periods.

RAFM actively promoted these miniatures rules through the 1980's at major conventions, such as ORIGINS, as well as historical miniature shows (such as HISTORICON) by hosting historical-based battles.

From the publisher:

"Trek through North, South and Central America, then cruise the Caribbean...and boost your knowledge of world geography along the way. In this self-checking game, the maps match when the answers are correct. Includes 100 laminated playing cards."
¡Oraciones Divertidas!, or Silly Sentences in English, is a game for Spanish children, meant to teach the basics behind sentences and some basic grammar.

Assault Gun is a set of free wargame rules for miniature wargaming WW2 large-scale battles. The game rules are freely downloadable from the Yahoo site - see Web Links.

In Assault Gun, one unit is typically either an infantry regiment or a battalion, such as tanks. This means that a large recognizable action of WW2 can be fought in a day with a manageable number of units.

Ready for download there are also several orders of battle (OOBS) covering units of armies, corps and divisions; and (presently) three full tested scenarios:
- Wintergewitter (Manstein's attempted relief of Stalingrad)
- Kasserine Pass
- the Battle of Hannut (France 1940)

item.description:
Quite simple card game by Leo Collovini. Players take tricks by making the sum of the numbers on the cards in the trick seven. (Guess it's the magic 7 the title mentions.)
Some special cards spice things up a bit. Game can be played with either 2 or 4 players.

In this Trivia Game two teams challenge each other. Each time it is your turn the other team draws a new category and read aloud 10 answers within this category. Only five of the answers are correct and you have to guess which!
Prior to guessing, you state the number of answers you think that your know (1 to 5) and if you are right in the selected ones, you are allowed to move the same number of spaces. If one or more of the answers are not correct you are not allowed to move at all.
Before you reach the end you must have collected three wooden rings.
This game is an educational game meant for Spanish children, involving making words out of the available syllables.

RATTLED is the fast paced word search game that will have you shakin' and makin words! Grab the handle, shake it up, then put it down. Both players (or teams) race to make the longest word possible from the eight scrambled letters.

The player who thinks he or she has found the longest word shouts it out and starts the timer. The opposing player has 30 seconds to find a longer word. The player who finds the longest word scores the point for the round. The first player to 20 points wins!

name.value: Thomas the Tank Engine's All Aboard Alphabet

item.description: All of the track letter cards are dealt out. The player with the letter A card starts by placing the card down and says "Thomas picks up an ____" and says one of the pictures on the card. The player with B follows and so on. Cards can also be used to teach the alphabet to younger children.

Warlord is an introductory miniatures game. In it, you command and army of warriors and monsters, which could include humans, dwarves, elves, orcs, goblins, even dragons and trolls.

Includes the use of fortresses, methods of attacking them, and various siege machines. Campaign rules are also included.

Noughts and Crosses ( Tic-Tac-Toe ) with a twist. Each row of the vertical board can be slid one space left and right. If, by moving the row a token moves over an empty spot below then it will drop. If the token is moved over the edge of the "board" then it drops out altogether. This means that only tokens placed in the middle column are safe from ever being ejected from the board.

The game has much more scope for strategy than normal Noughts and Crosses, either by (re)moving your opponents pieces or moving your own.

Gather the farm's animals!

4 farmers have lost their animals and have gone to gather them. But watch out! The animals will only follow their true owners! Witch farmer will be the first to gather all his animals?

(From the box - translated from Danish)

item.description:
Goal: Win the hockey game

Players move around the board drawing cards and doing what is says on the space. If you land on "VIDEO ATTACK" you go to the VCR to see what happens. It shows a great play from a game in the past. Either a goal or a save. If you see a goal you score a point.

Components:
1 hour long VHS video cassette
1 gameboard
40 coaches corner cards
40 wild cards
40 scoring pucks
2 dice
4 play pieces
1 official rule book

item.description:
The players have a chicken (or the rooster) with 6 different colors in front of them. Each color contains a hole, in which little balls with the according color have to be placed. Inside the cap of the game are 22 eggs, each egg having a ball with one of the six colors inside. In turn the players draw an egg and open it. Additionally to the colored eggs, there are white balls (joker) and a black ball. If a player draws the black ball, the chicken has to be cleared of all the balls collected so far.
The winner of the game is the one, who completes his chicken first. If he cries out: "Kikeriki, der Gewinner ist hie!" he gets the rooster in the next game.

From the manual: Teddy Bear Bingo helps the child increase attention span and develop sensory motor skills through the use of color motivation and colored teddy bears. Teddy Bear Bingo helps the child practice focusing visual attention through the use of color stimuli and eye-hand coordination by matching colored teddy bears to colored circles in a bingo game format.

Ídolos is a singing game based on the American Idol/Pop Idol TV show. Players assume the role of "wanna-be pop stars", and must sing their way up, with each duel eliminating one candidate. Every round a new music style is randomly selected; after each duel, votes are casted and the one who receives less points is eliminated.

But there is another catch: every player has a secret candidate, and the main goal of the game is to make him/her win the contest. And since each grade can only be used once, there is some strategy involved in the voting process.

item.description:
Players are leading an Enterprise. However they are not in good condition. They produce products for which there is not great demand and they have to stock those products in their warehouses. If they can't sell the products they have to dispose them if players do not set up their Enterprises "on demand" and do orientate their production on actual trends at the market.

This is a sponsored game. IBM (Switzerland) wants to show with this game how a "on demand" business works nowadays.

From the web site (http://www.stoneagescanners.com/golpe) using Google's Portugese to English translation:

Golpe (The Super Trunfo of the Brazilian Politicians) is a card game produced by the Stone Age Scanners based on 32 Brazilian politicians. . With it you can start battles with your friends and learn more on these important figures. It is provided for free to download, print and play.

Its creation deeply was inspired by the brilliant Super Trunfo de Santos Catholics. As well as this, its format is inspired in the Super “classic” Trunfo - that, in turn (little people know) it searches inspiration in the Top Trumps.

The game is available under the Creative Commons license.

One of seven in the line of Griddly Headz Boardgames, Nascar sees a different cast of “Griddly Headz” (regular Joes) duking it out on the racetrack for ultimate supremacy.

Played on a large, two-tiered board, Griddly Headz features the chance to choose both your drivers and how you match up them up against your opponent’s team.

Gameplay consists of numerous dice challenges that take place when two drivers meet on the same play square of the board; the loser forfeits a piece of their car (represented by puzzle pieces). If a player loses all twelve pieces of their car, or one of their Griddly Headz is ejected from the race, they are immediately eliminated from the game.

To win, you must score 180 points – fifteen points for each "tire toss" or "fastest crew" dice challenge won by your “regular” driver, and thirty points for each challenge won by your “emergency vehicle” (named “BP Bob”). Points can also be gained through special cards acquired during play.

Available in Special, Deluxe, Family, and Mini editions.

item.description:
One of seven in the line of Griddly Headz Boardgames, Football sees a different cast of “Griddly Headz” (regular Joes) duking it out on the gridiron for ultimate supremacy.

Played on a large, two-tiered board, Griddly Headz features the chance to choose both your team and how your individual players match up against your opponent’s.

Gameplay consists of numerous dice challenges that take place when two players meet on the same play square of the board; the loser forfeits a piece of gear (represented by puzzle pieces). If a player loses all twelve pieces of gear, or one of their Griddly Headz is ejected from play, they are immediately eliminated from the game.

To win, you must score 10 touchdowns (either touchdowns or kick returns) – one point for each touchdown or kick return dice challenge won by your “regular player”, and two points for each challenge won by your “quarterback”. Points can also be gained through special cards acquired during play.

Available in Deluxe, Family, and Mini editions.

Description (loosely translated) from eggertspiele Website:

As members of an imaginary corporation you try to improve the initially poor state of the company.
Each player represents one of four important powers in the firm:

-) The board of directors
-) The bank
-) The staff association
-) The labor union

As a representative of one of these powers, you can influence the other powers within the company using tokens.
Your aim is to most influential power in the company. However, your increased influence can have a negative effect on the whole firm...

There's only a winner if the company is successful in all areas. In this case it's the player with the most influence.

name.value: A Fatal Attraction: The Gallipoli Campaign

item.description:
Publisher's blurb:

A Fatal Attraction: the Gallipoli Campaign, is a wargame simulation of the 1915 Allied French and Commonwealth forces) offensive against Turkey.

In the beginning, it was Churchill's idea... a way of putting the old "pre-dreadnoughts" to useful service and making a show of strength in the waters off Istanbul which would, he said, cause immediate regime-change and take Turkey out of the war. It was thought very little infantry would be needed.

In the end, when the last Allied troops evacuated, the casualty count for both sides topped half-a-million. (And Churchill lost his job.)

And yet, the big naval attack had almost succeeded. The Allies would not know until after the war ended how close they had come to achieving their breakthrough on the Dardanelles. It was the first of many "what might have been" episodes, where success was just one more push, one more aggressive movement away...in contrast to many times when failure was reinforced and repeated.

Gallipoli is held as something sacred by the Australians and New Zealanders... as though they own it. The British would point out that the ANZACs made up less than 10% of the overall force and suffered less than 10% of the casualties. (But you can still get into a fight in Sydney if you talk like this!)

A Fatal Attraction brings this campaign of tragedy and opportunity to life. The counters represent brigades, batteries, and ships, and players have the chance to do better than their historical counterparts, while gaining a greater appreciation for the difficulties faced by both sides, including supply shortages, command/control difficulties, and random events.

With A Fatal Attraction, you'll find everything you need to understand Gallipoli except the smell and the flies.

Published in Against the Odds magazine #20, August 2007

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 week
Map: Area
Unit: Infantry Regiments/Brigades, Artillery Batteries and individual ships

Game Inventory:
One 22" X 34" mapsheet
One countersheet (280 1/2" counters)
One 12 page Game Rulebook
Four pages of chart & tables
Complexity - Medium
Solitaire suitability - Low
Playing time - Up to 6 hours

item.description:
A game for 2-4 year olds where they try to match an animal's nose to the card with a picture of that animal.
Features plastic animal noses and hard cards on which to put the noses.

item.description: Action game with spongy pills you bounce on the board to keep the cold bug away from your corner.

Two or 4 players gather to build a monolithic tower by placing a set of unique blocks on a foundation. The first player to fail to place their block, or to think they can't place their block loses.
This game features head to head play, and team play in partnerships of 2. There are 2 sets of 24 blocks made of reclaimed wood, a base with a 5×5 grid, and two bags for each player's blocks.
The idea in placing a block is to set yourself up with as many future options as possible while trying to eliminate placement options for the opponent.
This game is an excellent tool for teaching small motor skills and spatial recognition. It can be played by children age 6 and up. It's one of those games that take 5 minutes to learn, and a lifetime to master. It offers great replayability as each game is short, and each tower you build is unique.

Age of Iron is a set of rules for using miniature vessels to fight naval battles in the early years of the ironclad and steam powered ships. The rules are intended for fast play, so that large naval forces may be used with the conflict resolved to a conclusion in a reasonable time frame. Each turn represents 5 minutes. Scale is 1:1200 (60 inches = 1 mile).

Ten-sided dice are needed, as well as a random direction die or spinner. A ruler or tape measure is also required. Turn rate templates are provided, as well as status sheets that can be photocopied and used to record ship abilities.

The rules cover initiative, movement, fire, ramming, boarding parties, morale, fires, and naval versus land combat. Comes with reference charts, ship rosters with their game capabilities, and many ship templates.

name.value: Holy Hack: Hacking by the Book

item.description:
Holy Hack - Hacking by the Book (1996, Black Falcon Publications) is one of the "Hack" miniatures rules set, but this rules set specifically covers ancient warfare in the Biblical period. The rules are for either 25mm or 15mm miniatures, and while it recommends a basing system that is common with several other miniature rules sets (such as DBA, DBM, WRG 7th Edition, and WARRIOR), it allows for the use of any existing basing system the players currently use (an important consideration for miniature owners looking into a new rules set).

The rules cover the organization of miniatures into units, the variety of formations possible, and the importance of leaders and morale. Units are issued order chits (or blanks to confuse the opponent) at the beginning of the turn sequence, which commits units to specific actions for that turn. Orders are revealed simultaneously. The rules cover charges, movement, missile fire, and melee. Both missile and melee combat use damage tables with modifiers to determine casualties, which are converted into a percentage. Percentage dice (2 x D10's) are used to determine if a percentage fraction "hits" or not.

Although the rules use a casualty removal system, the most a side can lose is 3 figures per missile or melee round. Morale has a strong influence in the game, and the side that can force more morale tests upon his opponent will often win the game.

The rules come with a sheet of order chits/status markers, which can either be cut out or photocopied (using different colored paper can help to further distinguish the orders or unit status at a glance). This is not as complex a set of miniature rules as compared to Warrior, but it can get a bit involved for new players.

Description (loosly translated) from the eggertspiele-Website:

Lead your ancient people to victory!

A game where you can help your luck through good tactics.

The aim is to collect counters on the unusual game board. To do that, you move your two meeples on pre-defined ways. Movement is done via cards and a constantly changing multiplier.

It’s pedal to the metal as this collector’s edition of the Monopoly game brings you all the tension, tirades, and triumphs - American Chopper style. Celebrate Discovery Channel's most watched series as you go full throttle as you buy, sell and trade the Teutul’s most outrageous custom choppers. From the Black Widow Bike and Comanche Bike to the Jet Bike and POW/MIA Bike, relive the excitement and drama created by Paul Sr., Junior, Mikey and the entire Orange County Choppers crew as they race to complete their one-of-a-kind choppers.

The American Chopper edition of America’s favorite board game comes complete with 6 collectible pewter tokens including Paul Sr., Paul Jr. Mikey, the Tool Bike Tire, a welder’s mask and the Future Bike. Rules include a 60 minute speed play option for a shorter game with the same amount of fun. "Fire Her Up!"

Once again, villains lurk in the shadows of Gotham City. But darkness is on your side.

The Dark Knight can surely bring rule to an unruly world. Can you? From Crime Alley to The Penguin's Iceberg Lounge to the Batcave, now you can buy, sell and trade Gotham City’s most coveted real estate and take control of the city.

Defeat the enemies by taking control of their hangouts and become the ultimate crime fighter as you vie to own it all in this special edition of the world’s most famous board game, Monopoly. All components are customized to honor the “Guardian of Gotham City”. It’s time to bring justice to those who harm the innocent.

America’s favorite board game brings you the chance of a lifetime to buy, sell, and trade USA’s greatest cities from the East to the West coast. Celebrate life, liberty, the pursuit of happiness and… capitalism as you wheel and deal San Diego, Honolulu, Miami and more. Amass wealth and increase your net worth by creating USA vacation destination monopolies. Includes six collectible pewter tokens: Apple Pie, Mount Rushmore, Capitol Building, Liberty Bell, Bald Eagle & Statue of Liberty.

From publisher:

Children explore rhymes, sounds, sorting and classifying. The self-checking feature lets kids determine if a correct sort has been made- just check the back of each tile! Games are included for both independent play as well as with family or friends. Includes 4 category cards and 56 tiles. For 1-2 players. Ages: 4,5,6,7,8

One of seven in the line of Griddly Headz Boardgames, Soccer sees a different cast of “Griddly Headz” (regular Joes) duking it out on the field for ultimate supremacy.

Played on a large, two-tiered board, Griddly Headz features the chance to choose both your team and how your individual players match up against your opponent’s.

Gameplay consists of numerous dice challenges that take place when two players meet on the same play square of the board; the loser forfeits a piece of a player (represented by puzzle pieces). If a player loses all twelve pieces of a player, or one of their Griddly Headz is ejected from play, they are immediately eliminated from the game.

To win, you must score 10 goals – one for each goal or penalty kick dice challenge won by your “regular”, and two points for each challenge won by your “striker”. Points can also be gained through special cards acquired during play.

Available in Special, Deluxe, Family, and Mini editions.

Travel through Europe collecting souvenirs. The first player to get 25 Souvenir-Points (Stars) and return home wins the game.

Event cards can hinder your opponents, foiling their plans to visit a city before you.

item.description:
The game equipment for Spics consists of 36 pegs, 6 each of 6 colors, and a circular board with 36 holes arranged in 3 concentric rings. The holes are marked with the same 6 colors as the pegs, and are arranged so that no two holes of the same color are adjacent.

In the 2-player game, one player places 3-12 pegs in holes of matching colors, and the other player attempts to place the remaining pegs correctly from the back of the board - the holes go all the way through, and are not marked on the back. Points are lost for every incorrectly-placed peg. The players then switch sides.

In the 1-player game the player creates his or her own puzzle by placing pegs while trying not to pay attention to the other holes.

This is a chess variant played on a 10 x 10 board (included), with 4 extra pieces per side:

- Cyclops (next to the king). Can move 1, 2 or 3 spaces straight forward, capturing all enemy pieces there, and jumping all friendly pieces in the way; can also move 1-3 spaces backwards, capturing *all* pieces, enemy or friendly. Can be turned to a new facing direction after each move, or turn in place without moving.

- Archer (next to the queen). Moves and captures like a knight, plus it can "shoot" and capture a piece 3 squares away orthogonally while staying in place.

- 2 Super Pawns (in front of the king and queen). Like pawns, plus: on their first move they can hop over one square to the second square; at any time they can capture a piece 2 squares away diagonally forward, hopping any piece in the way if necessary.

from Spielbox:

A new Bremen-based publisher without a website as of yet. They will be releasing a game that apparently has been making the rounds of insiders for the past 10 years. The title: Paaren / Couples. It's a card-playing game. Each player plays cards. In one spot, one man can be matched with a suitable woman. Matches are determined by having at least two matching characteristics with both the location and the partner. These can be different, though. Players always have four characteristics, locations have two to six. There are influence cards which can break up matches as well as destroy them. Thankfully there are also other cards which offer protection against jealousy. The first player to reach a pre-set number of matches wins the game.

The game will be bilingual (German / English) and come with 120 individually illustrated cards. Since most will recognize the characters, it will be great fun to match those who might not seem to be such a good match to start.

Fast Play Naval and Boarding Party Action for ACW Iron-Clad battles. Includes charts and rules for Boarding Parties Shore Batteries etc. For both 15mm to 25mm.

While only a booklet-sized rulebook, BAPI provides profiles for most types of ironclads, monitors, and river boats. It also provides rules for damage, gun and crew losses, fire, etc. BAPI uses a random card activation system.

Jodie Press is a NON-PROFIT amateur wargame publishing operation. Jodie Press was formed to promote the hobby of Military Historical Wargaming by helping amateur wargame designers to publish, circulate and otherwise propagate their innovative gaming systems and wargame scenario/data books. Old Glory Inc. and various other distributors help distribute these rules worldwide, as well as through the Jodie Press web site.

Each player represents an elephant and tries to collect as many tree logs as possibles. The tree logs are placed on a treetop. A player pulls the cord of the tree trunk and the tree starts rotating. The game is afoot!

The players have to pick up the logs with their trunk, i.e. a tooter! In addition, the logs have to be placed in their own enclosure. Each log is worth 1 point unless it has a mouse on it. In that case, the log is worth -1 points. So if you pick up a mouse, you'll try to deliver this log to an opponent's enclosure!

The game ends if the tree is empty or stops rotating. The player with the most points wins. For a longer game, you can play several rounds to an agreed score.

For hygienic reasons, the tooters have separate mouth pieces that can be cleaned in a dish washer.

Ages 5-99.

item.description:
From the publisher:

Freedom isn’t Free!

In the crowded streets of Mogadishu sits a downed Blackhawk surrounded by a tyrannical warlord and his drug-crazed warriors. In the villages of Iraq lurk insurgents led by the ruthless al-Qaeda. In the arid desert of the Bakaw Valley is a terrorist training camp. In the mountains of Tora Bora lurks Osama bin Laden and his fanatical followers. Against these desperate foes are the most advanced armies ever created. But after the smoke from the smart bombs has cleared, it’s the infantry who must go in and finish the job.

These are today’s threats. These are Modern Ops.

Modern Ops lets you recreate the battles of the modern world, from regular military operations to special forces actions in Iraq, Afghanistan, the Soviet Union, and more. You’ll find complete troop lists for today’s combatants, including vehicles and aircraft, as well as our trademark Savage Tales and random Events that make every battle a surprise.

Modern Ops is a complete miniatures skirmish game. The Savage Worlds roleplaying game is NOT required.

Rules set for American Civil War naval miniatures. Rules feature ship sheets for over 30 Union and Confederate ironclads and other Civil War era ships including such famous vessels as the USS Monitor and CSS Virginia (Merrimack) as well as river ironclads, Forts and blockade runners. Rules designed to work for both 1/1200 and 1/600 scale. Publisher's website features over 30 additional ship sheets for downloading.

Object of the Game: To guess words correctly after hearing the first letter of a word, part of speech and it's definition, and to use the words in a story to score points.
Game includes three card decks of Nouns, Verbs & Adjectives, 2 special "parts of speech" dice, and a score pad.
Try collect cards by guessing the words correctly and then after gaining a certain number of cards, to then use those words in a story to gain points.

name.value: Peanuts: The Game of Charlie Brown and His Pals

item.description: Based on the Charles M. Schulz comic strip, this game has players rolling a die and moving around a board to Hideouts or the Booby Hatch in an attempt to collect a sequence of 5 cards (Charlie Brown and Violet; Schroeder and Lucy; Linus and Shermy; Patty and Pig Pen; and Snoopy), or 4 cards plus the "Peanuts" card. Contents are a board, 4 wood pawns, 21 cards, 1 die.

This chess variation uses the traditional pieces but is played on a board with a different topology: it's as if the board were pinched together in the middle, or as if the board were centered over the north pole of a globe, so all moves from the 4th to 5th rank pass through the center point. There is an extra file that prevents the two player's rooks from being adjacent; you cannot move through the outer two ranks of the file, you can move through but not stop in their inner two ranks. Diagonal moves for the bishops and queens are defined so that they make S-curves after passing through the center point, allowing for attacks that are hard to spot until you get used to them.

This set comes with a 2-sided board, a standard 8x8 board being on the other side; and it includes a checker set, so you can play Centre Checkers as well. Rules are included for all 4 games, chess and checkers, traditional and Centre.

Board Talk is a letter-by-letter word card game that uses a board for building up one's hand. During their turns, players roll 2 dice and move around the board. The space they land on allows them to get cards (1-3), lose a card, or use a particular letter with their cards to form a word. You may end the round by calling a word if it is 4 letters or longer. Similar to gin rummy, you get the points for the word you call only if it isn't beaten by another player. If beaten, the higher player gets your points *plus* his. After the scoring, the board and cards are reset, and another round starts. The winner is the first to reach the total point goal.

This game combines card and board play. At its heart, it's a letter-by-letter word game, where you spell words from your hand to get points. The Spellway track of the board keeps track of your total points, and the game is won by reaching the castle at the end of the track.

Several other features make it more like a board game race:

a) What you can do in your turn is determined by rolling a die and moving a shared piece around the S-track: you may draw 1-3 cards, discard a card, lay down a word, or draw a Spoiler card. Several junctions allow choices of play.

b) The Spoiler cards allow you to give and/or take letter cards from other players.

c) The Spellway track has some spaces that let you try to spell a random word on a Speller card, for 5 extra points. There are 2 levels of cards so different ages can play together.

d) If you play all your cards to spell a word, all the other players move back 1 space per card they hold, up to 3 max.

Players start with 20 points. A random 6-9 letter word is selected. Each player, in turn, must make an anagram of the current word, losing one point for each discarded letter and gaining one point if no letters are discarded. If no word can be formed, the player loses one point for each letter in the current word and selects a new random word. No word can be used twice in the game.

When one player has zero points, the game ends and the player with the highest score wins.

Strange Words was published (without the word list) in the Origins 2000 preregistration book. It was included in Chief Herman's Holiday Fun Pack.

Be the first to collect 3 large silver presents! Whoever said it's better to give than to receive never played My Precious Presents! In this game it is ALWAYS better to receive. This gift exchange is anything but civilized. Mischief abounds as everyone races to collect the biggest presents. Remember to keep your eyes on your pile of presents or else you'll end up with none!

Play revolves around managing and protecting your presents while sabotaging other players efforts. There are 120 cards in the deck, so a good variety of actions, reactions and other game play is possible. You will have to pay close attention to other players' victory conditions as once they are met the game is over.

Quick easy game play attracts all level of gamers and non-gamers alike. The back stabbing and action/counter action should keep players constantly on their toes.

69 colourful foil wrapped presents create instant buzz from onlookers.
